skill.name: latex-posters

Includes layout design, color schemes, multi-column formats, figure integration, and poster-specific best practices for visual communication.

security_audit.summary: This skill consists primarily of documentation, LaTeX templates, and a PDF quality check script. The shell script only runs standard PDF utilities (pdfinfo, pdffonts, pdfimages) on user-specified files for verification purposes. No network activity, no credential access, and no file system access beyond the user's input file. Safe for distribution.

content.value_statement: Academic researchers need professional conference posters but lack LaTeX expertise. This skill provides ready-to-use templates for beamerposter, tikzposter, and baposter with design guides and PDF quality checks.
actual_capabilities: Generate LaTeX research posters using beamerposter, tikzposter, or baposter packages
Apply evidence-based design principles including typography, color theory, and visual hierarchy
Create multi-column layouts with proper spacing and alignment for A0 and other standard sizes
Integrate high-resolution figures, QR codes, and institutional branding elements
Perform PDF quality verification including font embedding, page size, and image resolution
Follow accessibility guidelines for color-blind friendly palettes and contrast ratios
limitations: Does not generate figures or visualizations (requires separate figure creation tools)
Requires LaTeX distribution installation for compilation (TeX Live, MiKTeX, or MacTeX)
Does not provide printing services or file delivery to print shops
Templates serve as starting points requiring customization for specific conference requirements

use_cases.title: Conference Presentation Posters
use_cases.description: Create first conference posters with professional layouts and proper academic formatting standards.

use_cases.title: Institutional Research Posters
use_cases.description: Design visually compelling posters that meet specific journal or conference requirements.

use_cases.title: Poster Template Libraries
use_cases.description: Establish consistent poster templates matching institutional branding for research groups.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Poster
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a LaTeX research poster using [beamerposter/tikzposter/baposter] for a [topic] poster. The poster should be [A0/36x48 inches] in [portrait/landscape] orientation. Include sections for Introduction, Methods, Results, and Conclusions.

prompt_templates.title: Custom Design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a LaTeX poster template using [tikzposter/beamerposter] with [institutional/multi-color] branding. Include custom color definitions and layout guidelines for a [field] research poster.

prompt_templates.title: Quality Review
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my poster PDF for quality issues. Check page size matches [A0/36x48], verify font embedding is complete, and ensure all images meet 300 DPI resolution requirements.

prompt_templates.title: Complete Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Guide me through creating a complete research poster for [conference name]. Include template selection, content structure with word count guidelines, figure integration, design principles application, and final PDF quality checklist before submission.

output_examples.input: Create a research poster for a machine learning conference about neural network optimization
output: LaTeX template with beamerposter package configured for A0 portrait
Three-column layout with Introduction, Methods, Results sections
Design guidance: Sans-serif fonts (Helvetica), 72pt title, 36pt body text
Color scheme using IBM color-blind friendly palette
PDF review checklist with pdfinfo and pdffonts verification commands

best_practices: Limit poster content to 300-800 words total with 40-50% visual content
Use minimum 24pt body text for readability from 4-6 feet distance
Verify all fonts are embedded before printing using pdffonts command
Print a 25% scale test copy to verify readability before final printing
anti_patterns: Do not exceed 1000 words on a poster as viewers only spend 3-5 minutes reviewing
Avoid red-green color combinations as they are indistinguishable to color-blind viewers
Do not use small font sizes under 24pt as text becomes unreadable from distance
Avoid placing text directly on images without adequate contrast and spacing

faq.question: Which LaTeX poster package should I choose?
faq.answer: Choose beamerposter if familiar with Beamer, tikzposter for modern designs, or baposter for structured multi-column layouts. Each has distinct advantages for different conference styles.

faq.question: What are the standard poster sizes?
faq.answer: Common sizes include A0 (841x1189mm) for European conferences and 36x48 inches for North American events. Verify exact requirements with your conference specifications.

faq.question: How do I integrate figures into my poster?
faq.answer: Use includegraphics package for images. Ensure figures are 300+ DPI for print. Vector formats (PDF, SVG) are preferred for scalability. Include descriptive captions with key statistics.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using the PDF review script?
faq.answer: The review script only reads PDF metadata using standard tools (pdfinfo, pdffonts, pdfimages). No data is transmitted or stored. The script operates locally on files you specify.

faq.question: Why does my poster have large white margins?
faq.answer: Adjust margin settings in your documentclass. For beamerposter: set text margin left/right to 5mm. For tikzposter: use margin=5mm option. For baposter: add margin=5mm to documentclass.

faq.question: How does this compare to PowerPoint or InDesign?
faq.answer: LaTeX posters offer superior typographic quality, consistent formatting, and easy version control. However, they require LaTeX installation and have a steeper learning curve compared to WYSIWYG editors.
